posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
We attempted to get the WPILIB Swerve Pose Estimator up and going on a practice swerve drive this weekend but ran in to a problem where the Pose2D jumps around when the robot isn’t moving.

The swerve drive chassis drive fine with a joystick so kinematics is configured correctly.

We started with a pose estimator but encountered the problem to we simplified down to odometry object to see if the problem was still present.

We’ve noticed that the further from 0,0 the robot is the greater the jump is.  Typically the jump is towards 0,0 but not exact.

For a given Pose X/Y the jumps in the Pose X/Y are always to the same values.

We plotted the distances from each wheel and the imu heading to make sure nothing crazy was occurring in the raw signals.

We started looking into WPILib source.  From what we can tell it has to be in the ToTwist2d or Pose2D.Exp functions as everything else seems correct.

I will post a picture in a reply from my phone of the dashboard providing an example of the jumps.

posts.name: Kyle Reeve
posts.cooked: A github link or something would be helpful, to see the whole code in context. Are you incorporating Vision updates at all? If you’re still debugging this I’d suggest disabling vision updates for the time being. Also, double and triple check the signs of everything, make sure pushing every wheel forward causes the encoder values to go up, and that the code agrees with where the modules are facing, etc.

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
The problem is still present when using only the odometry object so vision updates aren’t relevant.

When moving, odometry works fine.  When sitting still it has massive jumps.

Given how odometry fundamentally works if the inputs are proven to not be changing then the resultant pose shouldn’t be jumps 10s of inches while sitting stationary.

Our team is currently in the camp of thinking this is a WPILib issue and not a bug in our code.

If everyone else is successfully using Swerve Odometry without problems then we’ll go debug our code or revert to our in house implementation we’ve been using.  We were hoping to pick up the pose estimation with vision updates by switching to the WPILib odometry.

In the past WPILib testing has been limited to unit testing and often times features are never tested on real hardware until the season starts and a team decides to use them.  I’m not faulting the WPILib team for this.  They are a great group of volunteers and they can’t be expected to test everything on complete robots when they don’t have them at their disposal.

I can’t provide a link to our entire code base.  If I need to I can work to strip out the drive train and create a minimal sample project that reproduces this.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
The only thing I can think of is there’s a singularity in the forward kinematics solve. I’d need to instrument SwerveDriveKinematics::ToTwist2d() with prints because that’s what SwerveDriveOdometry::Update() calls to generate twists for the pose exponential.

This seems like something that could be reproduced in sim, which means I can look into it when I find time.

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
TL;DR  - We are dumb…this isn’t an issue.

We had 2 instances of our DriveTrain Subsystem running.  We started with a sample project of the Swerve Poste Estimator.  We later beefed it up with a robot container but the original DriveTrain object in Robot.cpp was never removed.

We attempted to filter out the jumps and that wasn’t working and we weren’t able to detect them by comparing current and previous pose.  A few printf statements later and it was obvious their were 2 instances of the drive train running.

I apologize for wasting everyone’s time and being stubborn and not posting the full code base.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Glad you found your issue!

That said, I’d just like to pull out my soapbox for a moment to say that this is why it’s important to share your FULL code (ideally as a link to github or similar as mentioned by @kreeve ).  Snippets don’t show the full picture, so it’s very easy to overlook things like this.

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
In the past didn’t instantiating a motor controller with the same ID as another that has already been instantiated throw an error.  We enabled the other instance and we don’t see any errors like this.  The only evidence we see is the NavX is initialized twice.

I understand the desire to have full code bases available but the team will simply not allow the entire code base to be public until after the competition season is over.  At the time of creating this thread we didn’t think we were asking for help with our code we thought we were reporting a bug with WPILIB.

I realize the help we receive will be limited if we don’t post our entire code base.

Last year we spent 10 plus hours banging our heads against the wall thinking we had bugs in our code when in-reality they were in a vendors device firmware.  The vendor only had 2 major bugs last year if I recall but we fought both of them and lost a lot of time debugging them.  When we reached out to the vendor they were already aware of the bug and were working on a fix Given the limited time of mentors we’ve said if we spend a couple hours on a problem and it doesn’t appear to be in our code then we are going to report it as a bug.

Thanks for following up with the solution to your original issue. Not everybody takes the time or effort to do that.

If you suspect a bug in the library, it never hurts to create a minimal example that demonstrates the problem. Your team may be more willing to share a non-robot piece of code, but this also helps you to diagnose whether the problem really is external to your project code.

You shouldn’t be able to instantiate two motor controllers on the same port. That sounds like something you should root cause even though you’ve already fixed the problem with dueling drivetrains, otherwise whatever behavior is hiding in your system could come back and bite you later.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
kylelanman:

In the past didn’t instantiating a motor controller with the same ID as another that has already been instantiated throw an error.

We do that for PWMs, but CAN motor controllers are provided by vendor libraries and I’m not sure what behavior they’ve chosen to implement and/or change for duplicate IDs.
